text.p:
NEIL LAMONT , the author of the following poem , was the great - grandfather of John MacLean
( Bard Thighearna Chola ) ,
on the mother ’ s side . He must have been born in the early part of the eighteenth century as the event he celebrates here took place in the year 1757 .

ARCHIBALD MACPHAIL , a bard of considerable merit , lived in Baile - Phuil , and died there about 1830 . Mrs . Noble , of Cape Breton , the subject of Iain MacAilein ’ s finest lament , was the daughter of Fear - Ghrianail , the subject of this song .

’ S bochd an creachal th ’ air m ’ inntinn ,
Is chan urrainn mi ’ dhiobradh ,
Ma tha ’ n sgeula cho fior ’ tha iad ’ g raithinn !
’ S bochd an creachal &c .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p:
ARCHIBALD MACLEAN
( Gilleasbuig Laidir ) ,
was the tenant of Fear Chillmoluaig , also Archibald MacLean . The latter was tacksman of Kilmoluag . He married a daughter of Donald Campbell of Scamadale . He had three sons and two daughters , Donald , Charles , John , Anabella , and Mary . Donald and Charles both died in the West Indies . John succeeded his father in Kilmoluag . He was the father of the late Sir Donald MacLean , Governor of New Zealand .

Fhuair mi sgeula mo sgaraidh
Mu ’ n do mhiosaich an t - Earrach ,
Gu ’ n robh m ’ eudail ga bhannadh ,
’ An ciste chaoil air a sparradh ,
’ S tu air ghiulan aig fearaibh ,
’ S mnathan tursach dheth galach ;
Chi thu , Righ , gur trom eallach nan cairdean .
Chi thu Righ , &c .

text.p: DONALD MACDONALD , Domhnull Mac Iain Oig , resided in Croisgearr , between Croish and Carrachan , Kilmoluag . He was a great friend of Fear Chillmoluaig . He had a keen wit , as evidenced by the eleven comic songs of his preserved among the John MacLean MSS . He migrated to Barra , where he died in 1835 .

DOMHNULL CUBAIR was the brother of Iain MacAilein , Bard Thighearna Chola . He was a cooper by trade . He was married , and had a family of six daughters and two sons . The younger son was John
( Iain Ban ) ,
the father of the late Rev . Dugald Maclean , and of Archibald , Angus , &c . He died in 1868 at the advanced age of ninety - three years . The following lament was composed to his brother Charles who died alone in his boat in Tobermory Bay about 1811 .

The bard was still living at Caolas , and had not migrated to Bailephuil , where he reared his family . The occasion of the song was : — The cooper visited a still , but was not asked in . Shortly after departing , he was called back , as some of the casks were found to be in a leaking condition . The cooper showed no resentment , but immediately put things to right . He had his mild revenge in the above witty verses .

JOHN MACLEAN , IAIN MAC AILEIN ,
as he is called in his native Tiree , is more generally known as
“ Bard Thighearna Chola . ”
He was born at Caolas , Tiree , on the 8th of January , 1787 . He received a fair education , in Gaelic and English . He was a shoemaker by trade , and followed this calling till he emigrated to Nova Scotia in 1819 , where he settled as a farmer , at Bail - a - Chnoic in Barney ’ s River , Pictou County . While he was finishing his trade in Glasgow , he met and became enamoured of Isabel Black , a native of Lismore . They were married in 1808 , and had children , Christy , Charles , Archibald , John , Allan , and Elizabeth . In the year 1815 he travelled extensively through the Highlands , collecting the songs and poems of other bards . Some of these , along with his own works , he published in 1818 . Some of his best poems were composed in America ; notably , “ A ’ Choille Ghruamach , ” and the beautiful elegy on Mrs . Noble . He removed in 1831 to Glenbard , Antigonish County . His American works were published at Antigonish in 1856 . He died on 26th January , 1848 .
This eulogy was composed on the occasion of the bard ’ s receiving a letter of security from the Laird of Coll , when proceeding to Glasgow to procure a new stock of leather .
THE occasion of this song was a serious accident that befell the laird of Coll , who , while travelling in the Isle of Skye at night , fell over a cliff among the rocks .

THE bard had at this time collected a large number of unpublished songs and poems through the Highlands . These , with the help of the Edinburgh Highland Society , he hoped to publish . He was disappointed ;
THERE was at this time a lawsuit pending between the laird of Staffa and a Mr . Robertson who was notorious for his inhuman treatment of the Highland emigrants to America .

THIS touching lament was composed on the death by drowning of three Tiree men “ fast by their native shore , ” when returning from a business trip in Islay . They were Neil MacLean
( am Maor - Ban ) ,
Lachlan MacDonald , and Neil MacDonald , all belonging to Caolas .
THE subject of this song was the bard ’ s little niece , daughter of Domhnull Cubair . About ten years of age , she lived at the time in her grandfather ’ s house . The bard was still a bachelor .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: THE occasion was the marriage of the heir of Coll to a lady of considerable wealth . Hugh MacLean , yr . of Coll , is the subject of the poem .
JOHN MACFADYEN , the subject of the following verses , was a currier ; hence his dealings with the shoemaker bard . John was evidently a hen - pecked husband .

A bhean thuirt le greann oirr ’ , Ged gheibheadh tu bonn air ,
Cha phaigh e an call th ’ agad ann mar - a tha ;
Sin craiceann a ’ ghamhna ’ fhuair bas anns an t - samhradh ,
’ S a chairt thu le eubhuin* mu ’ n thionndaich am blaths .
* Eubhuin is a root used in lieu of oak - bark for tanning , found in Ceannamhara .
THIS song was composed to four herd laddies who were so intent on building a hut for their own comfort that they neglected their charges .

EOGHAN OG OF COLL is evidently acting in accord with the bard ’ s advice in a former poem composed on the occasion of the heir of Coll ’ s marriage . He had lately bought the estate of Benmore in Mull . Hence the bard ’ s rejoicing .

DONALD MACUALRAIG , or Kennedy , was a tailor and a fiddler . Tailors were often musicians in the olden days . Though many of them were crippled in the lower limbs , yet they could “ scrape and blaw . ” The subject of these verses was rather vain , but , at the same time , parsimonious to a degree . This song in his praise is but a biting satire . Donald was a native of Coll . The Tearlach MacCeoraidh mentioned was a Tiree man . The name suggests Mac Dheoraich , Dewar .
DUNCAN MACINNES was killed in battle in Holland . This lament is composed as by the sorrowing father .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: JOHN MACLEAN was a great admirer of the poems and songs of Corporal Alexander MacKinnon , the Morar bard . He obtained from the latter ’ s widow a perusal of his compositions , a number of which he incorporated in his own collection of 1818 .

Fhuair mi sealladh Di - luain
A dhuisg mo spiorad gu gluasad ;
Leubh mi dain a ’ bhaird luachmhoir nach beo .
Fhuair mi sealladh , &c .

CHARLES MACLEAN , a son of MacLean of Boreraig , settled in Tiree . His son , Archibald , became minister of Kilfinichen in Mull . Donald became tacksman of Kilmoluag , Tiree . The Rev . Archibald married a daughter of Campbell of Scamadale , by whom he had a large family . His son , Charles , married Catherine , daughter of MacLean of Muck . Archibald , their son , was the subject of this fine elegy .

THE above gentleman while on business in Inveraray was overtaken by a sudden illness , and died within four days . He had been married to Sheila , daughter of Campbell of Kilmartin , only a little over three months before .

JOHN CAMPBELL was a merchant in Scarinish . After seeing a drove of cattle to Doune , he proceeded to Glasgow to buy merchandise . On his way home , he became ill at Greenock , and was dead within three days . This was in 1817 .

THIS poem was composed shortly after the arrival of the Bard in America . It is evident that he was by no means satisfied with his new condition . He had to endure great hardships , unused as he was with the strenuous work involved in felling trees to make way for the plough , the initial poverty of pioneer settler , and the isolation of his lot . These things touched acutely the spirit of one whose life was company , who never did very hard work , and who never experienced extreme poverty before . However , long before his death he commanded a fair share of the comforts of life , made numerous friends , and was held in the highest respect by all who knew him . Nevertheless the poem , sent in a letter to his brother Donald in Tiree , is as true a description of the condition of things in the earlier years of his exile as pen could write . The poem

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: MRS . NOBLE , the wife of an eminent physician of Cape Breton , was the daughter of Colin MacNiven , Greenhill , Tiree . She died in 1843 , leaving a young family and a husband to mourn her loss . She was in the thirty - eighth year of her age . She was comely in person and beautiful in character . This elegy , perhaps the finest in the Gaelic language , was undertaken at the instigation of the bereaved husband , and composed in his name . It is evident that the poet ’ s heart was in his subject .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: THE words are put in the mouth of the father of a boy who was drowned on his way home from school .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: DIFFERENCE of creed did not prevent those two broadminded persons becoming and remaining fast friends . The following song in his praise shows that the Priest of Arisaig was possessed of many excellent qualities which lost nothing in the telling at the hands of the Bard . In the piece there is a description of a galloping steed that is almost incomparable . ( verse 5 ) .
The Rev . COLIN GRANT died in 1839 .

“ CUAIRTEAR NAN GLEANN ” was a famous periodical edited by the late Norman MacLeod , D . D . , “ Caraid nan Gaidheal . ” It had a wide circulation among the Gaelic people , and , next to the Bible , was the most esteemed publication that reached our Highland homes . The matter was wholesome , beautifully written , and well - designed for the class of its subscribers . A great many of its sermons and stories were from the inimitable hand of the editor . At the time of its existence purely Gaelic schools obtained in the Highlands of Scotland , so that its pages were perused with ease and even avidity . It was the time when the old dominie of the Eachann Tirisdeach type flourished . This song , composed about 1842 , welcomes the Cuairtear to America .

IN 1841 a Temperance Society was instituted in Antigonish by Bishop Fraser . Most of those under his spiritual guidance signed the pledge for a period of three years . The resolution was sealed on New Year ’ s Day . The song was made as if composed by Donald MacGillivray , commonly called “ Domhnull Mhamaidh . ”
IN a very short time , alas , the majority of the Antigonish Total Abstainers fell away . Hence this song made as by Raoghal Cubair , the local piper .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: ABOUT the year 1827 William Forbes of Pictou gave the Bard a large and beautiful horn full of brandy . Subsequently the Bard gave it to the Rev . Colin Grant , Priest of Arisaig , Nova Scotia . This poem takes the form of a conversation between the Horn and the Bard .

A FEW years after the Bard settled in America a ball was held in the house of David Murray in Merigomish ; no one was admitted to the ball except those who could speak Gaelic . An invitation was sent to the Bard , who showed his appreciation by composing the following song .

LEARNING from a letter from home that the Chieftain of Coll , his old and especial friend , had , through the exigencies of old age , handed over the family estates to his son , Eoghan Og , and gone to reside in Quinish , the Bard invokes the Muse once again on a theme that was dear to his heart .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: THE following anecdote is told of the Bard ’ s first acquaintance with Glengarry . At Falkirk Tryst he entered one of the refreshment booths , leaving the door open behind him . Glengarry , who was the head of the table , frowningly asked him if his father ’ s house had no door to it . “ It had , your honour , ” was the reply , “ but it was never closed on a stranger . ” From that moment the Bard could count Glengarry among his best friends .

CHARLES MACLEAN was the eldest son of Iain MacAilein , the poet . He was born at Caolas , Tiree , on 24th July , 1813 , and came out to Nova Scotia with the family in 1819 . He was a devout , kind - hearted , and much - respected man ; well - read and intelligent . He was the author of a number of excellent songs . He succeeded his father in Glenbard in 1848 , and died there in 1880 . He was unmarried .
THE above young Highlander was killed as the result of an explosion in a gold mine . After giving the details of the accident , the bard goes on to say : —

DUGALD MACEACHERN was born in Tiree in the spring of 1789 . He emigrated to Nova Scotia about 1820 . He was for some time a schoolmaster in Antigonish . He kept a boarding - house in Pictou for several years . He died in Boston , where he had gone to stay with his daughter Sarah , in 1880 . MacEachern was a good bard , as is evident from the following song , the only example of his composition that we have preserved for us . We only reproduce part of it here . The rest can be found in MacLean Sinclair ’ s Filidh na Coille .

THE Rev . JOHN MACLEAN , D . D . , was born at Clachanmore , Cornaig , Tiree , in 1841 , where his uncle was parochial schoolmaster . He graduated with First - class Honours in Classics and Mental Philosophy at the University of Glasgow in 1862 . He was minister successively of Kilchoman , Tarbert , and St . Columba ’ s , Glasgow . He was a man of solid character , quiet demeanour , full of restrained , pawky humour . It was in his early manhood in Kilchoman that he was tempted to court the Muse , his theme the love romance of a brother clergyman . As far as we know , this was his only venture in the realm of poesy . Dr . Maclean retired from active life in 1917 . He died in Glasgow two years later .

There was Bata Fhearchair .
Crew : Farquhar Macdonald , James Brown , Archibald Brown , Archibald Maclean
( am Port ) ,
John Macphail , and Archibald Maclean
( an Ciobair ) .
There was Donald Campbell ’ s boat in which were Clann Dhomh ’ uill Ghriasaiche .
These latterly emigrated to Canada . There was Bata ’ Mharsanta in which was am Marsant himself with his three sons . There was also Donald Maclean ’ s boat
( Domh ’ ull Cheann - na - Creige ) .
Crew : Donald Maclean , Alexander Macdonald , Colin Macdonald , Neil and Hugh Kennedy
( an Rudha ) ,
John Mackinnon , Sliabh .
This boat ’ s crew were all lost . The boat itself came ashore in Coll with Donald Maclean ’ s body in it . He evidently died of exposure . The sixth boat , and the last of which we have record , was Malcolm Macdonald ’ s . Its crew consisted of Macdonald himself and his sons , Archibald and Hector . They were picked up by Fearchair ’ s boat . Of the crew of the first boat , Malcolm MacArthur and John Campbell were washed overboard and drowned . In the second boat , Archibald Maclean ( an Ciobair ) died from exposure . This boat was driven to Islay where

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p:
THIS song was composed by the carpenter on board the China clipper “ Taeping , ” of which Captain Donald Mackinnon , Domhnull Mac Neaill ’ ic Dhomhnuill Ruaidh ,
Heanish , Tiree , was in command on the three notable voyages . The first of these was in 1864 , when he set up the record for the fastest voyage between Foo - chow - foo and London . This he accomplished in 88 days . That record , we believe , still stands . His ship , however , was not the first home that year , as he had the misfortune to meet with a typhoon in the China seas that nearly sent ship and crew to the bottom , and he had to have extensive repairs done to the gallant ship at Hong Kong . The following year , 1865 , Captain Mackinnon again beat all comers . This voyage occupied 102 days . The year 1866 witnessed what might be called a national event , in the memorable race between the China tea clippers for a prize of £100 . A remarkable coincidence saw seven of the tea - vessels crossing the bar of Foo - chow - foo practically together . But it soon developed into a close contest between the two Clyde - built ships , the Ariel and the Taeping , and commanded by two Scotsmen , Captains Keay and Mackinnon . For weeks and weeks they had lost sight of one another , until , as the song tells us , the Taeping outsailed them in a group when crossing the Line . Once more they lost sight of each other , and not till they were sailing up the English Channel did Keay espy a sail on the horizon that instinct told him was the Taeping . So close were the two ships together at Gravesend that it was touch and go

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: THERE is no doubt at all that the late Rev . John Gregorson Campbell , minister of Tiree , was the author of the following humorous song . His neighbour , Macleod of the Free Church , not only undertook the spiritual care of his flock , but also pretended to much skill in attending to their physical ailments , with disastrous results to a good few , and eventually to his own reputation . At the time of composing this song he advised his people to sell all the eggs they had and give the proceeds to the church . They were also enjoined to give up tea , tobacco , &c . , for the same laudable cause . The composition is dated , Tiree , November , 1879 .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p:
COLONEL CAMPBELL was factor for the Duke of Argyll , in Tiree , probably in the time of John Maclean ’ s boyhood
( Iain Mac Ailein ) .
It is an older bard , Archibald Macphail , Baile - phuill , that sings and laments his two stalwart soldier sons who fell in the Peninsular War . He also lauds the worth of Colin MacNiven of Greenhill , whose daughter , Julian , became the wife of Dr . Noble in Cape Breton , and was the subject of John Maclean ’ s most beautiful elegy . Macphail died about 1830 .

Coming back to Colonel Campbell , we find that in coming to Tiree he brought with him from Mull Eachann Ruadh Mac ’ Illeathain ( Hector Maclean ) who served as his ground officer . His great grandson , Neil , married Christina , daughter of Duncan Ban Mackinnon of Garadh Shoiribidh . This couple were the parents of John Maclean , Bard Bhaile - Mhartuinn ( Iain Mac Neaill ’ ic Iain ’ ic Iain ’ ic Eachainn Ruaidh ) .
Like Robert Burns , John was no great agriculturist , but he was a delightful poet . He was well - versed in the history of his country , and of the Highlands in particular . He was an unequalled wit , and often is brimming over with mirth already inwardly relished to the full . Even his sarcasm is so tempered that it is hard to take offence at his sallies . If Iain Mac Ailein had been poet - laureate of Tiree , Iain Mac Neaill would have been a worthy successor .

MacShimoin ort mar fhar - ainm ’ s MacArtuir anns an rinteal…
Taobh shiar Earraghaidheal chan nar e ri ’ chluinntinn .
Thu mhuinntir Thirithe ’ s an rioghachd tha fo thuinn ,
’ S cha leig thu Baile - Phuill as do chuimhne gu brath .

Sin thuirt m ’ aigne a clisgeadh ,
“ Tha thu ’ labhairt mar mhisgeir , ach duisg ;
“ Am fac thu idir an dig
“ Cham , dhoimhinn ’ bu lionmhor siuil ? ”
Luingeas roithean nan deann ,
’ S inneil sgolaidh nan teann - char dluth …
’ S an robh simeilear mor
’ Cur duibhr ’ air na neoil le ’ smuid .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p:
THIS famous tartan was designed by Mrs . MacLaren , Balemartin , who was the daughter of Uisdean or Hugh MacDonald . It was woven by Mrs . Hector MacLean , Cornaigbeg . The component colours were black , white and scarlet , “ Dubh , is geal , is sgarlaid ”
— not
“ Gorm is geal , is sgarlaid , ”
as in Mary Macpherson , the Skye bardess ’ song of subsequent date . The Tiree song was composed close upon sixty years ago , while the Skye version was honestly enough published originally as
“ Breacan Mairi Uisdein , air suidheachadh ur ”
— a new setting . The following is as nearly as possible the original form of the song as composed by John Maclean , Tiree .

[Ged ’ s lionmhor bainneach sporsail a
Tha chomhnuidh anns an duthaich ,
Gu ’ n dh ’ fhairtlich orra spal a chur
’ Am breacan Mairi Uisdein . ]
THIS song was composed to the MacLeans who emigrated from Baile - phuill to Manitoba about 1877 .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p:
’ S e Baird a b ’ fhearr a dheanadh sin
Na ministeirean diomhanach ;
Bodaich ruighinn , riamalach ,
’ Tha ’ toirt nan ciad bho ’ n Stata . *
* The bard here falls into the common error of believing that the stipends of Parish Ministers are derived from the State .

The Bard composed the former of the two preceding songs , “ Hi horo ’ s na horo eile , ” as if by Mary MacDonald to her future husband , Duncan MacDonald . He is made to reply in “ A ’ Chailinn Mhaiseach Dhonn . ”
The following two verses are added from another hand in order to make the beautiful lyric of less fragmentary proportions for singing .

John Maclean was , at the time of composing this song , Bard to the Clan MacLean Association , Glasgow . He had received an invitation to be present at the Annual Gathering of the Association , and was thereby moved to compose the reply here produced . The Clan raised an appropriate monument to his memory in Soroby Graveyard .

ALEXANDER STEWART was a son of Alasdair a ’ Ghaidseir ,
and was born in Glasgow about 1859 . He was brought up by an aunt in Caolas , Tiree , since early childhood . He was a bard of unquestionable merit . He has a sense of style and rhythm , and an easy flow of apt diction . His humour is inoffensive , and his more serious productions indicate soundness of thought . One should expect him , had he lived to riper years , to attain to a high place among our Gaelic Bards . He was only twenty - five or twenty - six years of age when he was accidentally killed in MacLaren ’ s Ironworks , West Street , Glasgow .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: The following verses are by another hand .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: ARCHIBALD MACPHAIL was born and reared at Cornaigmore , Tiree . Even as a boy he was noted for his wit . He composed a good number of songs , mainly of the humorous order . They were all very clever , but in many of them the personal reference is rather thinly veiled , if at all ; so that there are many living that would be ready to take offence at passages pointed at their forebears that were by no means complimentary . The bard was a shoemaker to trade . Later , he and his brother Lachlan became joint tenants of the farm of Croish . Archibald died there in 1889 . His daughter , Mrs . Lamont , now occupies the farm .

The subject of the following song was a young lad , Hugh Munn , who was engaged by the Cornaigmore crofters as herdboy , for the lordly sum of £1 in the half - year . Among notoriously careless guardians of crops our hero was evidently outstanding ; so that when this eulogy was recited to the old men , they rose in wrath with one accord against the author , till they realised the keenness of his satire .
The foregoing song was composed to Catherine Sinclair — Catriona Ni ’ n Iain ’ Ic Chaluim ’ an Goirtein - Domhnuill , latterly Mrs . Neil MacKinnon , Ibrox .

While Archibald Macphail was still single , and carrying on his shoemaking trade in his father ’ s house , he was visited one day by a neighbour newly home from the herring - fishing on the east coast . He had brought home with him one of the tiniest of clay pipes . He filled and lit this toy , and passed it to the bard . The latter having eyed it for a moment broke into spontaneous verse as follows : —
The owner of the pipe was Hugh MacLean , Carnans .

DONALD BROWN was a near neighbour of Macphail — Domhull Mac Eoghain Bhruin . Of his verses we have only succeeded in bringing one to light . He had a dog called Toby , who , in company with a neighbour ’ s dog , Peitean , was caught sheep - worrying on the farm of Hough . The result was that the dog was destroyed and his master heavily fined . That was the occasion of the song , of which this verse was part . The Brown family emigrated to Canada .
Peitean was a dog belonging to Iain Mac Chaluim , who at the time ( 80 or more years ago ) lived on a spot now occupied by the Turner ’ s house .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p:
JOHN MACDOUGALL or MACLUCAS was the son of Rev . Duncan MacLucas , who was for many years a Baptist minister in Tiree . He lived at Balephuill . John composed many songs . The most notable of them are the subjoined . He died in the prime of life , about 1875 . His brother Duncan
( Donnachadh Beag )
was also a ready wit and good bard . Of his works we only know one verse of the parody on “ Eilean an Fhraoich . ” This was composed when he was being plagued by Lewis fishermen at the east coast , who sought him to sing on every opportunity this popular song . It seems he could sing it uncommonly well . After this explanation , we do not anticipate that anyone will take offence if we submit this impromptu verse .
Afterwards , Duncan was relieved of the Lewismen ’ s importunity .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: CAPTAIN ANGUS LAMONT was born in Lagnancruach , Cornaigmore , Tiree , about the year 1844 . He was the son of John Lamont , farmer , cattle - dealer , and merchant there . Being a lad o ’ pairts he entered Glasgow University as a medical student . The lure of the sea , however , was too much for him , and he soon deserted the healing profession for the romantic calling of the mariner . Having served his apprenticeship with the famous Hall Line , he rapidly rose to the position of master . He was only about forty - four years of age at the time of his death , which took place on board his ship at San Francisco . There he was buried with Masonic Honours in the Ancient Order ’ s burial - ground . He was the author of a number of songs . Unfortunately , the only one we have been able to procure is the well - known “ Lagnancruachan . ” Another song of his , was composed when the Oban and Callander Railway , as yet , only reached Dalmally , and while the author was awaiting at this place a conveyance to take him to Oban on his way to Tiree . The chorus is : —

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p:
JOHN MACLEAN
( Iain Mac Dhomh ’ uill ’ ic Eachainn )
was a native of Balephuill , Tiree . He was the son of Domh ’ ull Griasaiche , whose sons were involved in the fishing disaster of 1856 , but escaped with their lives . With the exception of Archibald , who tenanted a small holding in Balemartin till his death a few years ago , they all emigrated to Canada in 1878 . This event is worthily celebrated by John MacLean , Balemartin , in his touching song , “ Gur muladach mise . ” In “ Oran Mhanitoba , ” by John MacLean , Balephuill , “ Ghlac Mac ’ Illeathain an t - searrag ’ na laimh ” refers to Mr Lachlan MacLean , Lachainn Mac Eoghain , who left Cornaigbeg for Canada shortly before . Mairi was Mairi ni ’ n Alasdair , an aged servant who was left behind ; but , determined to be still one of the loved family , she proceeded to join them on the first opportunity , sailing in company of clann Ghilleasbuig ’ ic Neaill who left lower Cornaigbeg the following year . Our bard , though of indifferent health , lived to a good age . He was a genial soul , and was always a welcome guest at the homes of his fellow - islanders whom he was in the habit of visiting frequently in the adopted country .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p:
Ach a mhuinntir Ghoirtein - Domh ’ uill ,
Ged is mor ’ ur boilich ,
Saoil an tig sibh suas ri Tomas*
Nuair ’ theid an cota dearg air ?
* The Author .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p:
MAIRI UISDEIN , Mrs . Maclaren , was a native of Balemartin , Tiree , and was the designer of the famous tartan , the surpassing glory of which was delightfully sung by John Maclean , the Clan Bard of the Macleans . The editor ’ s grandmother was the weaver of
“ Breacan Mairi Uisdein . ”
The song here submitted shows that Mairi was also a successful wooer of the Muse .

JOHN MACPHAIL , the author of the following pieces , was born at Clachanmore , Tiree , in the year 1846 . Archibald Macphail , Croish , was his maternal uncle . John was a tailor to trade . For a number of years he prosecuted his calling in Bunessan , Mull , with the firm of Charles M ‘ Quarrie & Son . He afterwards removed with his family to Hynish , Tiree , and thence to Cornaigmore . After the death of his brother , Lachlan , he settled in Clachanmore where he was born . He died after undergoing a serious surgical operation , in the Western Infirmary , Glasgow , on the 20th October , 1909 , in the sixty - fourth year of his age . He was the author of a number of songs of considerable merit , but his outstanding production is the Lament on his brother , William , who died of scarlet fever in the early flower of manhood .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: The above verses were composed by John Macphail , Clachan , in praise of Mr . Donald Mackinnon , F . E . I . S . , who was awarded the “ Highland News ” Prize at Inverness ( 6th Mod ) for having the highest percentage of passes in Gaelic of all the competing schools in the Highlands .
THIS song won the first place in a competition inaugurated by the Tiree Association a number of years ago .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: IT was for long thought that Archibald Macphail , Croish , was the author of this humorous ditty . The actual composer was his nephew , John Macphail , Clachan . The scene was laid in Balevullin . The verses we have been able to append here explain all that is necessary .

A MAN of considerable wit and facility of speech in prose or verse was James Macfarlane , Balemartin , the father of four ministers ; John , James and Duncan , of the Baptist Church ; Robert , of the Church of Scotland , for many years the respected minister of Glenorchy and Innishail .

James MacFarlane , whose ready wit we have already noticed , went to see John MacLean , Tacksman of Kilmoluag , a man of giant proportions . MacFarlane wore a very shabby tile - hat . MacLean ’ s fine headgear was placed on the table at his elbow . As soon as he appeared Kilmoluag sternly rebuked MacFarlane for daring to come to visit him in such shabby attire ; especially the hat . Without hesitation James replied ,

B ’ e sud am bata snasmhor ,
Bu tlachdmhor i air cuan ;
Le ’ h - acain laidir dhubailte
Gu siubhlach ’ dol mu ’ n cuairt ;
Ged ’ thigeadh stoirm cha diultadh i ,
A stiuradh troimh gach stuagh…
Iain Mor ’ s e cumail uilidh orr ’ ,
’ S am pourie aig air chluais .

’ S ann againn bha na passengers
Nach faca mise riamh ;
Bha Albannaich is Sasunnaich ,
A tigh ’ nn o ’ n Ear ’ s o ’ n Iar ;
Bha Deasaich agus Tuathaich ann ,
’ S gu ’ m b ’ uasal leam an gniomh …
’ S m ’ fhear - duthcha , Calum Camshron ,
Le ’ chaile chalma chiar .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: THE hero of this song was a shipmate of the author , John Brown . He was a fireman , and , like many of his hard calling , was much addicted to drink . As the bard tells us , he had often to go to sea very short of stores , and it was a stark fact that the money that should have bought the Christmas goose was spent on strong drink .

w.pos: A V A N V A
w.lemma: buail buail buailt buailt buailt buailte

text.p:
JOHN MACLEAN
( Iain Mac Lachainn na h - Urbhaig )
was born at Caolas , Tiree , on the 21st February , 1867 . He was the son of Lachlan MacLean , son of Mary MacLean , daughter of Neil MacLean , brother of Iain MacAilein , the bard . He followed the sea for a living .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

w.pos: A V A N V A

an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: At the time these verses were composed the Old - Age Pension was of the original amount of 5s . a week . Mrs . Archibald Macdonald , the authoress , was a very fine old lady , respected and revered by all who knew her . It was from her , undoubtedly , that her gifted son , Donald Macdonald , derived his poetic talents and much of his genial nature . Her daughter , Euphemia , is also a successful wooer of the Muse .
The foregoing song was composed by Donald Macdonald in Ottawa , Canada , on January 22 , 1912 . The glowing hope to see his native isle , as indicated in the song , was doomed to disappointment .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: The following ditty was composed by Alexander Macdonald , Donald Macdonald ’ s young son , now a lawyer in Canada , when the family was sojourning in Colonsay , and when Alasdair was scarcely 12 years of age . The subject of the song was a favourite dog .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p:
MARY FLORA MACDONALD was the daughter of Donald MacDonald
( Domhnull Uibhisteach ) ,
who was for many years a highly respected member of the City of Glasgow Constabulary . He belonged to a family who migrated from Caolas , Tiree , to the island of Barra . After industriously tilling their farm in Barra , when the harvest - time came , they were deprived by the ruthless natives of the time of all the fruits of their labours . They then set out for Uist , and in S . Uist established a more peaceful and lasting home . A sister of Donald MacDonald was the mother of John R . Bannerman , Rathane , worthy father of a worthy son , John M . Bannerman . Than John R . Bannerman ( who , by the by , came with his parents and two sisters , the late Mrs . James MacPherson and Mrs . Archibald MacCulloch , to Glasgow at the tender age of four years ) there is not a better or more enthusiastic exponent of Gaelic poetry and prose in the Gaelic movement . This cousin of his married Mr . Archibald MacDonald , farmer at Aird - a - Deas , in Caolas , Tiree . She had a short but happy married life . On the mother side she was a niece of Archibald MacPhail , Croish , and so might be expected to be well able to woo the Muse . The few examples we here submit will justify us in giving her an honourable place among the Tiree Bards .

Domh ’ ull Erchie mo charaid ’ na shuidh ’ anns a ’ chaithir ,
Gur ro - mhath gu gabhail nan oran e .
’ S e gillean mo ruin , &c .

Bidh Donnachadh a farraid , An d ’ thainig Niall Ailein ?
No ’ n do thoisich e fhathast air roiteachas ?
’ S e gillean mo ruin , &c .

Mur ’ n tig Ioraig oirnn dhachaidh , ’ s gu ’ n teid i ’ Lochabar ,
Gu ’ m brosnaich sinn Lachainn gu posadh , O .
’ S e gillean mo ruin , &c .

Alasdair Chaluim , ’ bu tric a bhiodh againn ,
Chan fhaic sinn ach ’ n dara Di - domhnaich e .
’ S e gillean mo ruin , &c .

NEIL MACLAINE was born at Caolas , Tiree , on the 1st of May , 1851 . He was the son of Lachlan Maclaine
( Lachuinn Taillear )
and Ann MacLean , the daughter of Neil Maclean , brother of John MacLean , Bard Thighearna Chola . As a boy he went to sea with his uncle , Niall Og . After a short sea - faring experience , he served his time as an apprentice joiner . This trade he followed for practically the rest of his life . He went to the Kimberley Diamond Fields in 1880 . Returning home in 1884 , he opened a boot and shoe warehouse in Paisley Road , Glasgow , but he did not continue long in this business . He married in 1885 Catherine Macfadyen , the sister of John Macfadyen , the well - known Mull Bard .

Neil S . Campbell , the subject of the above song , was a notable member of the Bellahouston Harriers . He is a builder to trade , and in pursuit of his calling spent some years in South Africa . He returned to Glasgow , and started business on his own account . His venture has met with success . From the beginning he has taken a deep interest in the Tiree Association . He has been for a number of years a vice - president of the Association , and last year has been elected president , in succession to Mr . Hugh Alexander Low — an honour well - earned .
The Camshronach above referred to was Dr . Charles Cameron , M . P . , afterwards Sir Charles Cameron . Mac ’ Ille - Bhain was Mr . Henry Whyte — “ Fionn . ”

text.p: Note . — Hector MacFadyen , a worthy Tireeman , who was for many years Treasurer of Ceilidh nan Gaidheal , was the winner of many prizes at the National Mods . He was a zealous Gael . He died in Glasgow twelve or thirteen years ago .

Note . — The race from China to London was won by Captain Donald MacKinnon , Heanish
( Domh ’ ull Mac Neaill ’ ic Dhomh ’ uill Ruaidh )
in the tea clipper , Taeping , in 1866 . He is the Domh ’ ull Ban referred to .
CUMHA NAN LEODHASACH . *
* The Iolaire disaster .

text.p: SUNNY TIREE .
This is the poem that won the Bard ’ s Crown at the Fort William Mod , 1927 .

text.p:
Deorsa† th ’ air an ailm gu h - uallach ,
’ S e ri fuaradh ’ cumail cair oirr ’ ;
Sud am fleasgach ’ sheasadh cruadal —
Shiubhladh cuan air slige bairnich .

Cairdean th ’ air an traigh gu lionmhor ;
Tairngidh iad air tir gun dail i ,
’ S iad ri gairdeachas bho ’ n thill sinn :
’ S e mo dhith nach eil MacPhail* ann .

† Captain George Ritchie .
* Angus MacPhail , Postmaster at Iona , died 1932 .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: NEIL CAMPBELL COLQUHOUN , the author of the following verses , was born at Sliabh Dearg , Caolis , Tiree , where his father was parochial schoolmaster , on the 15th of August , 1864 . His father , Archibald Colquhoun , was born at Moss , Tiree . His mother was Mary Ann Maclean , only daughter of Iain Ban , a great worthy , who lived and enjoyed life to the patriarchal age of 107 . Archibald Colquhoun after leaving Tiree kept school at Petty , Inverness - shire , and latterly was Gaelic teacher and catechist at Eastside , Kilmuir , Skye ; also at Waternish , and lastly at Elgoll in the Parish of Strath . He died at the age of fifty - nine , and was buried in Kilmaree , Strath , Skye . Neil Campbell was born , remained , and is , a perfervid Tirisdeach . He was one of the founders of the Comunn Tirisdeach , and is now an active member of the executive of that Association . He is the author of many pieces , Gaelic and English . The following three short pieces we deem worthy and suitable for publication here .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: ALICK MACDONALD , Milton Cottage , Caolas , is the son of the late Archibald Macdonald , for many years pilot on the S . S . “ Handa ” ( formerly the Aros Cas . ) His two sons , Alick and Donald , are captains of large ocean - going vessels , and both have composed good verses . The one subjoined is the only specimen to hand . It is the composition of the above Alick Macdonald .

ALEXANDER SINCLAIR
( ALASDAIR NEAILL OIG )
is a wine and spirit merchant in Glasgow . He has on not a few occasions successfully captivated the Muse . He is a devoted Tireeman , taking a deep and active interest in The Glasgow Tiree Association and in all that pertains to the welfare of his fellow - islanders at home and from home . His brother Donald , now for many years in America , also gave evidence of poetic talent in “ Oran na Van , ” which , we are sorry to say , we can only submit in a fragmentary condition . It was composed about 1882 , and proclaimed the advent of the first van that hawked goods around Tiree . It always announced its arrival at any station by a loud blast on a trumpet . Hence the allusion in the song to Righ na Mointich mistaking it for the distress signal of a ship ashore .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p:
Nuair dh ’ fhag i Grianal ’ s a thug in iar oirr ’
Gu ’ n chuir i fiamhachd orr ’ aig Cuil - Bhoid :
Is thuirt an t - Iasgair , ’ S e ’ th ’ ann an Riabhach
Le chuibhlean iaruinn is bras ’ s a ’ chorr ;
Ach glacaibh ciall agus bithibh rianail ,
’ S theid mis ’ a dh ’ iarraidh an Abstoil Phoil — *
Ni esan urnuigh air son ar stiuraidh ,
’ S gu ’ n leag e ’ chursa gu dluth troimh ’ n cheo .

* Paul was Archibald M ‘ Fadyen ,
Baile - Mhic - Bheotha .

DONALD MACDONALD was on his way to Canada with his brother , when , at the Tail of the Bank , he fell into the hold of the emigrant ship . He was fatally injured , and died in a Greenock hospital a few days after . These sad verses were composed by his sister , Mor , evidently out of a full heart . This was about 1856 .

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: BY THE EDITOR .

text.p: ARCHIBALD MACLEAN , the turner , is the best known residenter in Tiree . He has lived where he was born over eighty years ago , and practically never left his native island . Yet there is not a Tiree - man at home or abroad who has not heard of him , and who has not some anecdote to tell of him . Spinning - wheels of his manufacture are world - famed , and grace the drawing - rooms of royalty . But it is the sharpness of his wit and the aptness of his quick retort that have given him a unique place in the respect and affection of his fellow - islanders . He is a most hospitable soul , a dutiful neighbour , and a faithful friend . With him the scathing epithets of an acid tongue usually veil the sincere regard of honest esteem .
